author: Samuel Rubenfeld
title: Corruption Currents: Malaysians Transfixed as Purses, Cash, Jewelery Are Seized
text:
0 COMMENTS Malaysian police take away boxes of seized goods during a night raid in Kuala Lumpur early Friday on three luxury apartments owned by former prime minister Najib Razak's family.
A daily roundup of corruption news from across the Web. We also provide a daily roundup of important risk & compliance stories via our daily newsletter, The Morning Risk Report, which readers can sign up for here . Follow us on Twitter at @WSJRisk.
Bribery:
U.S. authorities deported a former Russian businessman convicted of arranging bribes in a nuclear case. (RFE)
The U.K. House of Lords will review the Bribery Act to assess its effect on small businesses. (FT)
The Burmese finance ministry is investigating bribery allegedly encouraged by the customs director. The article didn’t include a response from the director. (Irawaddy)
A suspect set to go on trial for bribery in Sweden emigrated back to Russia. (OCCRP)
Patrick Ho, a former Hong Kong minister accused in the U.S. of corruption and bribery, was denied bail for a third time. (SCMP)
Local cases: An Indonesian transportation official was sentenced to five years in prison for taking bribes. A Buffalo, N.Y., developer pleaded guilty in a corruption case. (JP, TU)
Cybercrime:
Streaming service Tidal is investigating a data breach amid reports it inflated figures on how often works by its top artists were streamed. (Pitchfork)
Fraud:
Singapore is seeing a spike in white-collar crime and it is targeting cyber resilience in finance. (Nikkei, ST)
Money Laundering:
The owners of Mugshots.com were charged with extortion and money laundering. They couldn’t be reached. (Gizmodo, WP, BuzzFeed, PBP)
Nigerian authorities filed money-laundering charges in a case against officials. One was quoted as saying he will defend himself. (ThisDay)
Two brothers in Arizona were charged with money laundering linked to a political-action-committee scam. Lawyers for the pair didn’t respond to requests for comment. (AP)
The sentencing of Rabobank NA in its money-laundering case came through . (ToSD)
Indonesian authorities are investigating money-laundering cases . (Tempo, JP)
Sanctions:
Iran signed an oil deal with a U.K. consortium as other firms exit due to the U.S. leaving the nuclear agreement. The oil deal comes as London seeks a waiver from U.S. sanctions. The U.S. and Europe are bracing for a showdown over how Swift will react to the U.S. exit. A German bank announced its Iran exit, as did a Polish gas firm. Will China benefit from the U.S. exit? (AP, RFE/RL, AC, WI, Platts, FT, Reuters, Reuters, SCMP)
Viktor Vekselberg, a U.S.-blacklisted Russian oligarch , paid back his western debts as part of a plan to get his company out of sanctions. (CNBC, Reuters, FT)
A Belgian company blacklisted over its alleged ties to Hezbollah denied those purported links. (Reuters)
Washington threatened sanctions over an oil project linking Russia and Germany. (Bloomberg, AP)
The U.S. sanctions leveled against Venezuela’s second-most powerful official didn’t stop an election held over the weekend. (Reuters, WSJ)
Democratic lawmakers want an investigation into the delayed implementation of U.S. sanctions on Russia. (DB, Economist)
France froze the assets of a Chinese firm over its alleged links to the Syrian weapons program. (AFP)
The U.S. added to its export-control entity list. (FR)
General Anti-Corruption:
Malaysians have been transfixed with the seizures of handbags, jewelry, cash and other items taken from residences belonging to the former premier as part of a re-energized corruption probe . The inquiry put the former first lady in the spotlight. The family vehemently denied the allegations , and asked for protection from death threats. Luxembourg wants more information from authorities about the status of frozen funds linked to the investigation. (Reuters, AP, CNN, WWD, Reuters, WP, ST, Reuters, Reuters, Rappler, FMT, Reuters, WP, Today, Reuters)
It is difficult to know if there is any corruption behind the purported sale of 666 Fifth Avenue to Brookfield Properties, in which the Qatari government has a significant stake. (Slate, NYT, SCMP)
Portuguese soccer club Sporting confirmed that its premises were searched as part of a corruption probe. (PN)
A Bosnian tycoon-turned-politician was cleared of corruption charges. (Reuters)
New York City’s investigations department launched an ad campaign targeting corruption. (NY1)
The Council of Europe told the U.K. to be more proactive in its fight against government corruption. (OCCRP)
Data firm Cambridge Analytica’s final days before its liquidation are detailed here . (NBC)
Details of the U.S. investigation into the Trump presidential campaign came into focus as the heat increased over the ongoing U.S. special counsel’s probe . Roger Stone expects to be indicted. (NYT, NYT, Politico, MSNBC, Reuters, Reuters, Politico, Bloomberg, NPR)
